The Alcazaba of Málaga has a rich history and has been witness to several notable events, some of which are listed below:

- During the 11th century, the Alcazaba was constructed on the orders of King Badis of Granada, who ruled the region at the time. The fortress was built to protect the city from possible invasions.

- In the 13th century, the fortress was captured by the Christian King Ferdinand III during the Reconquista, which marked the end of Islamic rule in the region.

- The fortress was later used for several purposes throughout history, including as a military barracks, prison, and even as an artillery workshop.

- In the 20th century, the fortress was transformed into a museum and tourist attraction and was declared a National Monument.

- In 1937, the Spanish Civil War reached Málaga. The fortress was used as a prison during this time, and thousands of people, mostly civilians, were held there before being executed.

- In 1975, the fortress was used as a location for the filming of the movie "The Wind and the Lion," starring Sean Connery and Candice Bergen.

- Since the 1990s, the fortress has been used as a venue for cultural events, including music and theater performances.

Overall, the Alcazaba of Málaga has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be an important cultural and historical landmark.
